subsection.title: Reading Function Values from a Graph
subsection.p: The Dow-Jones Industrial Average (DJIA) gives the average of the stock prices of 30 major companies. The graph below shows the DJIA as a function of time during the stock market correction of October 1987. The DJIA is thus f(t), recorded at noon on day t of October.

The values of the input variable, time, are displayed on the horizontal axis, and the values of the output variable, DJIA, are displayed on the vertical axis. There is no formula that gives the DJIA for a particular day; but it is still a function, defined by its graph. The value of f(t) is specified by the vertical coordinate of the point with the given t-coordinate.

ol.li: The coordinates of point P on the DJIA graph are (15, 2412). What do the coordinates tell you about the function f?
If the DJIA was 1726 at noon on October 20, what can you say about the graph of f?
The coordinates of point P tell us that f(15) = 2412, so the DJIA was 2412 at noon on October 15.
We can say that f(20) = 1726, so the point (20, 1726) lies on the graph of f. This point is labeled Q in the figure above.

subsection.p: Thus, the coordinates of each point on the graph of the function represent a pair of corresponding values of the two variables.

assemblage.title: Graph of a Function
assemblage.p: The point (a, b) lies on the graph of the function f if and only if f(a)=b.

statement.p: Write an equation that says that the point (8,17) lies on the graph of g.
Which equation says that the point (8,17) lies on the graph of g?

introduction.p: The water level in Lake Huron alters unpredictably over time. The graph below gives the average water level, L(t), in meters in the year t over a 20-year period. (Source: The Canadian Hydrographic Service)

image.description: graph of Lake Huron water level

li.p: The coordinates of point H on the graph are (1997, 176.98). What do the coordinates tell you about the function L?
The average water level in 2004 was 176.11 meters. Write this fact in function notation. What can you say about the graph of L?
L(1997) = 176.98; the average water level was 176.98 meters in 1997.
L(2004) = 176.11. The point (2004, 176.11) lies on the graph of L.

statement.p: The water level in Lake Huron alters unpredictably over time. The graph below gives the average water level, L(t), in meters in the year t over a 20-year period. (Source: The Canadian Hydrographic Service)

image.description: graph of Lake Huron water level

li.p: The coordinates of point H on the graph are (1997, 176.98). What do the coordinates tell you about the function L?
The average water level in 2004 was 176.11 meters. Write this fact in function notation. What can you say about the graph of L?
L(1997) = 176.98; the average water level was 176.98 meters in 1997.
L(2004) = 176.11. The point (2004, 176.11) lies on the graph of L.

subsection.p: Here is another way of describing how a graph depicts a function.

assemblage.title: Functions and Coordinates
assemblage.p: Each point on the graph of the function f has coordinates (x, f(x)) for some value of x.

statement.p: The figure shows the graph of a function g.

ol.li: For what value(s) of t is g(t) = -2?
What is the largest, or maximum, value of g(t)? For what value of t does the function take on its maximum value?
On what intervals is g increasing?
To find g(-2), we look for the point with t-coordinate -2. The point (-2, 0) lies on the graph of g, so g(-2) = 0. Similarly, the point (5, 1) lies on the graph, so g(5) = 1.

We look for points on the graph with y-coordinate -2. Because the points (-5, -2), (-3, -2), and (3, -2) lie on the graph, we know that g(-5) = -2, g(-3) = -2, and g(3) = -2. Thus, the t-values we want are -5, -3, and 3.
The highest point on the graph is (1, 4), so the largest y-value is 4. Thus, the maximum value of g(t) is 4, and it occurs when t = 1.

A graph is increasing if the y-values get larger as we read from left to right. The graph of g is increasing for t-values between -4 and 1, and between 3 and 5. Thus, g is increasing on the intervals (-4, 1) and (3, 5).

introduction.p: Refer to the graph of the function g shown in .

li.p: List the value(s) of t for which g(t) = 0 . Separate different values with commas.
What is the smallest, or minimum, value of g(t) ?
Minimum:
For what value of t does the function take on its minimum value?
Select all the intervals listed below where g is decreasing.
From -5 to -4?
From -5 to -2?
From 2 to 4?
From 1 to 3?

statement.p: Refer to the graph of the function g shown in .

li.p: Find ~g(0).
For what value(s) of t is ~ g(t) = 0 ?
What is the smallest, or minimum, value of g(t) ? For what value of t does the function take on its minimum value?
On what intervals is g is decreasing?

webwork.pg-code: $fofx = RadioButtons( ["It is not possible for the function \(y=f(x)\) to take on the same \(y\)-value at two different \(x\)-values.", "The maximum value of \(y=f(x)\) may occur at two different \(x\)-values.", "The maximum value of the function \(y=f(x)\) is the largest \(x\)-value that appears on the graph.", "\(f(x)=0\) at the \(y\)-intercept of \(f(x)\)."], 1, );

statement.p: Which of the following is true?

solution.p: The maximum value of y=f(x) may occur at two different x-values.

statement.p: Which of the following statements is true?

li.p: It is not possible for the function y=f(x) to take on the same y-value at two different x-values.
The maximum value of y=f(x) may occur at two different x-values.
The maximum value of the function y=f(x) is the largest x-value that appears on the graph.
f(x)=0 at the y-intercept of f(x).

technology.title: Finding Coordinates with a Graphing Utility
technology.p: We can use the TRACE feature to find the coordinates of points on a graph. For example, graph the equation y = -2.6x - 5.4 in the window

Press TRACE, and a “bug” begins flashing on the display. The coordinates of the bug appear at the bottom of the display, as shown in the figure. Use the left and right arrows to move the bug along the graph. You can check that the coordinates of the point (2, -10.6) do satisfy the equation y = -2.6x - 5.4.
The points identified by the Trace bug depend on the window settings. If we want to find the y-coordinate for a particular x-value, we enter the x-coordinate of the desired point and press ENTER.

subsection.title: Constructing the Graph of a Function
subsection.p: Although some functions are defined by their graphs, we can also construct graphs for functions described by tables or equations. We make these graphs the same way we graph equations in two variables: by plotting points whose coordinates satisfy the equation.

statement.p: Graph the function f(x) = \sqrt{x + 4}

solution.p: We choose several convenient values for x and evaluate the function to find the corresponding f(x)-values. For this function we cannot choose x-values less than -4, because the square root of a negative number is not a real number. f(\alert{-4}) =\sqrt{\alert{-4} + 4}=\sqrt{0}= 0 f(\alert{-3}) =\sqrt{\alert{-3} + 4}=\sqrt{1}= 1 f(\alert{0}) =\sqrt{\alert{0} + 4}=\sqrt{4}=2 f(\alert{2}) =\sqrt{\alert{2} + 4}=\sqrt{6}\approx 2.45 f(\alert{5}) =\sqrt{\alert{5} + 4}=\sqrt{9}=3 The results are shown in the table.

Points on the graph have coordinates (x, f(x)), so the vertical coordinate of each point is given by the value of f(x). We plot the points and connect them with a smooth curve, as shown in the figure. Notice that no points on the graph have x-coordinates less than -4.

webwork.pg-code: $fof3 = RadioButtons( ["Find 3 on the \(x\)-axis, move vertically to the point, then horizontally to the \(y\)-axis.", "Find 3 on the \(y\)-axis, move horizontally to the point, then vertically to the \(x\)-axis.", "Substitue 3 for \(x\) into the formula for the function.", "Substitue 3 for \(y\) into the formula for the function."], 0, );

statement.p: How do we find the value of f(3) from a graph of f?

solution.p: Find 3 on the x-axis, move vertically to the point, then horizontally to the y-axis.

statement.p: How do we find the value of f(3) from a graph of f?

li.p: Find 3 on the x-axis, move vertically to the point, then horizontally to the y-axis.
Find 3 on the y-axis, move horizontally to the point, then vertically to the x-axis.
Substitue 3 for x into the formula for the function.
Substitue 3 for y into the formula for the function.

technology.title: Using Technology to Graph a Function
technology.p: We can also use a graphing utility to obtain a table and graph for the function in . We graph a function just as we graphed an equation. For this function, we enter Y_1 = \sqrt{\,}(X+4) and press ZOOM 6 for the standard window. The graph is shown below.

statement.p: Let f(x) =
Complete the table of values and sketch a graph of the function.

solution.p: The graph is shown below.

statement.p: Let f(x) = x^3 - 2
Complete the table of values and sketch a graph of the function.

solution.p: We evaluate the function at each value of x. For example, f(\alert{-2}) = (\alert{-2})^3 - 2 = -8 - 2 = -10 You can verify the completed table and the graph with your technology tools.

statement.p: How is graphing a function different from graphing an equation?
How is graphing a function different from graphing an equation?

subsection.title: The Vertical Line Test
subsection.p: In a function, two different outputs cannot be related to the same input. This restriction means that two different ordered pairs cannot have the same first coordinate. What does it mean for the graph of the function?

Consider the graph shown in figure (a) below. Every vertical line intersects the graph in at most one point, so there is only one point on the graph for each x-value. This graph represents a function.

In figure (b), however, the line x = 2 intersects the graph at two points, (2, 1) and (2, 4). Two different y-values, 1 and 4, are related to the same x-value, 2. This graph cannot be the graph of a function.
We summarize these observations as follows.

assemblage.title: The Vertical Line Test
assemblage.p: A graph represents a function if and only if every vertical line intersects the graph in at most one point.

statement.p: Use the vertical line test to decide which of the graphs in the figure represent functions.

li.p: Graph (a) represents a function, because it passes the vertical line test.
Graph (b) is not the graph of a function, because the vertical line at (for example) x = 1 intersects the graph at two points.

For graph (c), notice the break in the curve at x = 2: The solid dot at (2, 1) is the only point on the graph with x = 2; the open circle at (2, 3) indicates that (2, 3) is not a point on the graph. Thus, graph (c) is a function, with f(2) = 1.

webwork.pg-code: $ver = RadioButtons( ["A) If the graph is a vertical line.", "B) If the graph is increasing.", "C) If the graph is decreasing.", "D) If the graph is a function."], 3, );

statement.p: What does the vertical line test tell us?

solution.p: The vertical line test tells us if the graph is a function.

statement.p: What does the vertical line test tell us?

li.p: If the graph is a vertical line.
If the graph is increasing.
If the graph is decreasing.
If the graph is a function.

introduction.p: Use the vertical line test to determine which of the graphs below represent functions.

solution.p: Only (b) is a function.

statement.p: Use the vertical line test to determine which of the graphs below represent functions.

solution.p: Only (b) is a function.

subsection.title: Graphical Solution of Equations and Inequalities
subsection.p: The graph of an equation in two variables is just a picture of its solutions. When we read the coordinates of a point on the graph, we are reading a pair of x- and y-values that make the equation true.

stack.p: For example, the point (2, 7) lies on the graph of y = 2x + 3 shown at right, so we know that the ordered pair (2, 7) is a solution of the equation y = 2x + 3. You can verify algebraically that x = \alert{2} and y = \alert{7} satisfy the equation: \text{Does }~\alert{7} = 2 (\alert{2}) + 3\text{?} ~~~~~~~~ \blert{\text{Yes}}

subsection.p: We can also say that x = 2 is a solution of the one-variable equation 2x + 3 = 7. In fact, we can use the graph of y = 2x + 3 to solve the equation 2x + 3 = k for any value of k. Thus, we can use graphs to find solutions to equations in one variable.

statement.p: Use the graph of y = 285 - 15x to solve the equation 150 = 285 - 15x.

stack.p: We begin by locating the point P on the graph for which y = 150, as shown in the figure.
Next we find the x-coordinate of point P by drawing an imaginary line from P straight down to the x-axis. The x-coordinate of P is x = 9.
Thus, P is the point (9,150), and x = 9 when y = 150. The solution of the equation 150 = 285 - 15x is x = 9.

solution.p: You can verify the solution algebraically by substituting x = \alert{9} into the equation:

statement.p: If f(8)=2, what point lies on the graph of f?
If f(8)=2, what point lies on the graph of f?

note.p:
The relationship between an equation and its graph is an important one. For the previous example, make sure you understand that the following three statements are equivalent:
The point (9, 150) lies on the graph of y = 285 - 15x.
The ordered pair (9, 150) is a solution of the equation y = 285 - 15x.
x = 9 is a solution of the equation 150 = 285 - 15x.

li.p: Use the graph of y = 30 - 8x shown above to solve the equation 30 - 8x = 50
Verify your solution algebraically.
The point on the graph where the y-coordinate is 50 is the point (-2.5,50), so x=-2.5 is the solution.
We verify that we have an identity when we substitute x=-2.5 into the equation 30 - 8x = 50.

conclusion.p: We verify that we have an identity when we substitute x=-2.5 into the equation 30 - 8x = 50.

li.p: Use the graph of y = 30 - 8x shown above to solve the equation 30 - 8x = 50
Verify your solution algebraically.
The point on the line where the y-coordinate is 50 is the point (-2.5,50), so x=-2.5 is the solution.

subsection.p: In a similar fashion, we can solve inequalities with a graph.

stack.p: Consider again the graph of y = 2x + 3, shown at right. We saw that x = 2 is the solution of the equation 2x + 3 = 7. When we use x = 2 as the input for the function f(x) = 2x + 3, the output is y = 7. Which input values for x produce output values greater than 7?

You can see that x-values greater than 2 produce y-values greater than 7, because points on the graph with x-values greater than 2 have y-values greater than 7. Thus, the solutions of the inequality 2x + 3 \gt 7 are x\gt 2. You can verify this result by solving the inequality algebraically.

statement.p: Use the graph of ~y = 285 - 15x~ to solve the inequality 285 - 15x \gt 150

solution.p: We begin by locating the point P on the graph for which y = 150. Its x-coordinate is x = 9. Now, because ~y = 285 - 15x~ for points on the graph, the inequality 285-15x \gt 150 is equivalent to ~y \gt 150.

So we are looking for points on the graph with y-coordinate greater than 150. These points are shown in red on the graph. The x-coordinates of these points are the x-values that satisfy the inequality. From the graph, we see that the solutions are ~x \lt 9.

statement.p: You are using a graph of f(x)=48-3.5x to solve the inequality 48-3.5x \gt -15. You find that f(18)=-15. Your answer is:
You are using a graph of ~f(x)=48-3.5x~ to solve the inequality ~48-3.5x \gt -15~. You find that ~f(18)=-15. What is the solution to the inequality?

li.p: Use the graph of y = 30 - 8x above to solve the inequality 30 - 8x \le 50
Answer:
Note: Use " \lt= " for the \le symbol, and use " \gt= " for \ge .

As we found in the previous Checkpoint, the point on y=30-8x where y=50 occurs when x=-2.5 . The y -coordinates are smaller as we move to the right on the graph, that is, for the points where x\ge -2.5 .
Use the graph of ~ y = 30 - 8x~ above to solve the inequality 30 - 8x \le 50

As we found in the previous Checkpoint, the point on y=30-8x where y=50 occurs when x=-2.5 . The y -coordinates are smaller as we move to the right on the graph, that is, for the points where x\ge -2.5 .

subsection.p: We can also use this graphical technique to solve nonlinear equations and inequalities.

statement.p: Use a graph of ~f(x) = -2x^3 + x^2 + 16x~ to solve the equation -2x^3 + x^2 + 16x = 15

solution.p: If we sketch in the horizontal line y = 15, we can see that there are three points on the graph of f that have y-coordinate 15, as shown below. The x-coordinates of these points are the solutions of the equation.
From the graph, we see that the solutions are x = -3, x = 1, and approximately x = 2.5. We can verify each solution algebraically.

For example, if x = \alert{-3}, we have \begin{aligned}[t] f(\alert{-3})\amp= -2(\alert{-3})3 + (\alert{-3})^2 + 16(\alert{-3})\\ \amp= -2(-27) + 9 - 48\\ \amp =54 + 9 - 48 = 15 \end{aligned} so -3 is a solution. Similarly, you can check that x = 1 and x = 2.5 are solutions.

statement.p: Use the graph of y = \frac{1}{2}n^2 + 2n - 10 shown above to solve \frac{1}{2}n^2 + 2n - 10 = 6 and verify your solutions algebraically.
statement.instruction: Separate different values with a comma.

statement.p: Use the graph of ~ y = \frac{1}{2}n^2 + 2n - 10 ~ shown above to solve \frac{1}{2}n^2 + 2n - 10 = 6 and verify your solutions algebraically.

solution.p: We look for points on the graph that have y-coordinate 6. The n-coordinates of those two points are the solutions, n = -8 and n = 4. To verify the solutions we evaluate the function at n = -8 and n = 4 to find \frac{1}{2}(\alert{-8})^2 + 2\alert{-8} - 10 \amp = 32 - 16 - 10 = 6 \frac{1}{2}(\alert{4})^2 + 2\alert{4} - 10 \amp = 8 + 8 - 10 = 6

webwork.pg-code: $dec = RadioButtons( ["If its \(x\)-values increase from left to right.", "If its \(y\)-values decrease when its \(x\)-values decrease.", "If its \(y\)-values decrease when its \(x\)-values increase.", "If the graph lies below the \(x\)-axis."], 2, );

statement.p: When is a function called decreasing?

solution.p: A function is called decreasing if its y-values decrease when its x-values increase.

statement.p: When is a function called decreasing?

li.p: If its x-values increase from left to right.
If its y-values decrease when its x-values decrease.
If its y-values decrease when its x-values increase.
If the graph lies below the \x-axis.

technology.title: Using the Trace Feature
technology.p: You can use the Trace feature on a graphing utility to approximate solutions to equations. Graph the function f(x) in in the window

and trace along the curve to the point (2.4680851, 15.512401). We are close to a solution, because the y-value is close to 15. Try entering x-values close to 2.4680851, for instance, x = 2.4 and x = 2.5, to find a better approximation for the solution.

statement.p: Use the graph in to solve the inequality -2x^3 + x^2 + 16x \ge 15

solution.p: We first locate all points on the graph that have y-coordinates greater than or equal to 15. The x-coordinates of these points are the solutions of the inequality.

The figure below shows those points in red, and their x-coordinates as intervals on the x-axis. The solutions are x \le -3 and 1\le x \le 2.5, or in interval notation, (-\infty, -3] \cup [1, 2.5]. (See Appendix A.2 to review interval notation.)

statement.p: Use the graph above from Practice 7 above to solve the inequality \frac{1}{2}n^2 + 2n - 10 \lt 6
Answer:
statement.instruction: Note: Use interval notation or inequalities.

solution.p: -8 \lt n \lt 4 , or in interval notation, (-8,4)

statement.p: Use the graph above from Practice 7 above to solve the inequality \frac{1}{2}n^2 + 2n - 10 \lt 6

solution.p: In Practice 6 we found that \frac{1}{2}n^2 + 2n - 10 = 6 when n=-8 and n=4. Looking at the graph, we see that points with y-coordinates less than 6 make up the lower portion of the parabola. They have x-coordinates between n=-8 and n=4. Thus, the solutions are ~ -8 \lt n \lt 4 , or in interval notation, ~(-8,4)

statement.p: Explain how to use the graph of y=x+\sqrt{x} to solve the equation x+\sqrt{x}=56.
Explain how to use the graph of y=x+\sqrt{x} to solve the equation x+\sqrt{x}=56.
